data.title: INTENT + VISION
questions: In this phase, imagine a successful workshop.
What’s your intent? What is the purpose of the workshop?
What would you like to create as a result of this meeting?
Envisioning a successful outcome, what do you see?
What’s the deeper meaning of this workshop?
How would you describe and communicate its significance?
How do you see the workshop taking people forward?
What’s your ‘gut’ or intuition telling you about it?
How can you ensure your vision becomes reality?

data.title: PEOPLE + CULTURE
questions: In this phase, understand the attendees and how they should interact.
Who must attend (i.e, in order to achieve the purpose/objective)?
What purpose, role and/or function does each person represent?
How will you communicate each person’s responsibility?
What do the attendees need to know prior to the workshop?
How will you engage each person to fully contribute?
How will you establish a ‘safe space’? Build community?
How will you ensure individual and group needs are met?
If an established group, what cultural norms need challenging?
How will you leverage or challenge group/corporate cultural norms?
How will you encourage participation given group dynamics?
How will you need to facilitate to reach a successful conclusion?

data.title: OBJECTIVE + AGENDA
questions: In this phase, define the objective and design a flow to achieve it.
Establish & communicate the purpose and goal of the meeting.
Why is it important? Connect its objective to a larger purpose.
Determine the best process/agenda for the audience and topic.
How will the design achieve the outcomes you desire?
Define and communicate each person’s role/responsibility.
Give sufficient notice, and confirm attendance in advance.
Distribute pre-work sufficiently in advance to complete.

data.title: TIME + PLACE
questions: In this phase, attend to the details of holding the workshop.
Accurately estimate and communicate how long it will take.
Choose the best location/technology given the meeting type.
Choose a venue/space that reflects the meeting’s goals and values.
Choose a seating layout that elicits the kind of interaction desired.
Ensure everyone knows how to use the technology; test it in advance.
Ensure sufficient privacy. Eliminate or minimize interruptions.
Identify what pre-work would accelerate the group’s readiness.
Propose ground rules (see separate module) given group dynamics.
